displayed_text: Patient: Okay. Patient: Okay, is that early enough? Would that be early enough? Could that be early? Doctor: Would you like it? Patient: Oh yes, we’d like eight thirty? Doctor: You’d like that today. Okay. I will request; I’ll say eight a.m. if possible. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I’ll request, I don't know if its available, but I hope it is; if it’s eight a.m., it will be earlier. Patient: That will be fine. Doctor: So that will be for the appointment itself. So we’ll sign that. And then the next step will be to order the PSA and the testosterone the week before Patient: Could you also include the um, my diabetes AC. Doctor: The A1C. Patient: Yes, A1C and I could just give them to my doctor.

Family Member: So what is – can he take anything to help him sleep? Like natural? Doctor: You can try melatonin. Family Member: Melatonin. That’s right. Doctor: I suggest stop drinking at seven p.m. and you’ll be a miracle. You won’t even get up that much. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Then you’ll say, oh, my, gosh, I’m awake and I didn’t get up. Patient: I’ll go with that line of action first. Doctor: And then you’re going to say, boy, that doctor, she’s really smart. (Laughter) Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Be sure you don’t like, you know, sleep so hard that you forget to pee if you actually have to pee. Doctor: I’m just saying seven p.m. Okay. Bye. Patient: Okay. So I got – she took – oh, I do, right here. Doctor: You do have sheet to go.

Patient: I’m not one. Doctor: Yeah. Exactly. Patient: It’s amazing uh well one thing I’m really fortunate with is that um I’m at a state of mind where I just that kind of helps me when I’m making decisions. So it’s not like Doctor: is that cancer care has become so expensive. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: companies charge for their services Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: -and for that immunotherapy six hundred thousand dollars. So Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: We’re trying not to let the insurance companies … for a different indication and insurance companies… Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: you have five FDA approved therapies. (xx)

Patient: Okay. Doctor: That keeps you from having the side effects. And she’ll give you a prescription. That’s the only other thing we’ll give you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Unless you think of anything else. Patient: The testosterone and the shot. Thank you very much. Have a good week. Doctor: All right. I’ll be waiting. Healthcare Professional: The effects of Doctor: Three days from now. Patient: Dad, do you need anything are you going to play golf now? Family Member 1: No, I’m not going out.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? So we have um two or three uh radiation oncologists here that specialize in that type of therapy for prostate cancer patients. And the other things that are I want to discuss um with you today is a clinical trial – Patient: Okay. Doctor: - where we’re using that type of therapy but instead of not using it and not following um patients and getting data from them, we want learn something from their experience. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: And also want to compare the outcomes of patients who get the stereotactic radiotherapy immediately versus those that are observed for a period of time and then we’ll get the stereotactic radiotherapy a little bit later. PAT; Okay. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And um the person running the trial is a baseball fan so he has the Oriole trial. Doctor: We call it the Oriole trial. And um basically I will give this consent form and you can take it home to read through. Uh um, ORIOLE basically stands for for observation versus stereotactic radiation therapy for all metastatic prostate cancer. Um, the word means few. Like . And what does metastatic prostate cancer mean a few metastases, so it means few Patient: Um, hmm. Doctor: - you are eligible for this type of therapy for this trial. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: So in this trial, the ORIOLE part is defined as having three or fewer.

Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Now, on the scans, there was a little bit of growth in the lymph nodes. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Okay? The lymph nodes in your belly are getting slightly larger. So we are going to have to change your treatment and add different other treatments to this. Okay? Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So one of the treatments is a combination of a bone medication, it’s a radiation that goes to your bones, along with the immune therapy. Family Member: Okay. And that’s the injection he has? Doctor: No. Family Member: No? Doctor: No. The injection he has right now is uh, the hormone therapy, the Lupron. Family Member: Yeah. Okay. Doctor: That will continue. Family Member: Okay.

Patient: Took you a while. Doctor: It takes a while and up to a year, you know, we don’t get too anxious about treating you aggressively until you get to a year as far as the sexual function is concerned. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: So uh yeah I think that uh… Patient: I don’t have pain you know nowhere, but every now and then you know I guess I’ll probably <___> to but other than that I feel, I feel good. Doctor: Okay, that’s good. Patient: You know, I feel good. Doctor: That’s good. Let’s see and you’re sixty… Patient: No I’m fifty-nine. Doctor: Fifty-nine. Patient: I’m not sixty yet. Doctor: Yeah.

Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So we have to check everything. Family Member: Wow. Doctor: Yeah. So there’s no sticking or biopsies but it’s a blood draw. And you have lots to spare. So don’t say, “Oh, my, God”. Doctor: “She can take this ten and that’s it. I’m rolling out of here.” No. You have lots, and lots, and lots of blood to donate. Okay? Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: Oh, and, let me not forget that you’re also a candidate for a study called, Iron Man. Family Member: Hum. Doctor: Which is an international study where you would there donate once a year a tube of blood, or is it two? Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And you fill out questionnaires to share with people about your journey. You know? How is this helping? Not helping? What don’t you like? Family Member: Oh.

Patient: And you’d maintain the care? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: That’s very important. Patient: Okay and uh okay. Yeah we’ll look at the consent form. It sounds more complicated. Doctor: Because one side, yeah so there is – I think what I’ll do is I’ll give you the consent to read through and then we’ll set up a time to come in downtown with the potential for doing all the testing needed if you decide you’re okay with proceeding. Patient: And we were planning to go on a cruise in February. Doctor: Okay. That should be fine still. Patient: Really? Doctor: Yeah. I don’t see any reason to cancel that. Family Member: Unless you want to – so it doesn’t matter whether we sign the consent today or that day to you. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: So when’s the next time I come in to I guess there? There’s no way of doing it here? Doctor: It’s too much.

Patient: No. Doctor: You didn’t notice any different? Doctor: Okay so should we try going to five once a day or you don’t want to rock the boat? Patient: I suppose we could try it and see what happens. Doctor: We’re gonna try it. Family Member: Or even five one day and two the next and five one day and two the next. Doctor: I was just gonna say or maybe do it every other day. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: And see how you do. Patient: Yeah I can do that. Doctor: Because now if you’re not aggregating it with this medication… Patient: Oh yeah, yeah.

Patient: Give, give that some thought, too. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Like maybe it’s, if you think it is worthwhile doing since I’m already trying with the testosterone to do it, uh. Doctor: Okay. Patient: You can follow a number of avenues. Doctor: I could ask the pharmacist if there’s a way that, you know, if the patient could actually just pay for it themselves and just get it. Family Member: Um hum. Patient: Yeah. It is one injection and then watch it? Doctor: Uh usually it’s, it’s IV, it’s every three weeks for as far as it works. So it could be you know- Patient: A year? Doctor: I don’t know what that all costs, but uh- Family Member: But do you know right away after one or two?

Patient: Right, right. Doctor: Depending on and the changes if they’re more than fifty percent – Patient: I don’t know chuckles]]. Doctor: - I’m okay with trying for it. Family Member: So what was that kaypo? Doctor: K-Y-P-H-O-P-L-A-S-T-Y. Kyphoplasty. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. But again you know these are things to ask him. Family Member: Right. Doctor: I don’t know if that… Patient: Well he had to get another… Family Member: Myogram.
